entry.title: OCaml, modules, and import schemes
entry.summary: The [OCaml](https://ocaml.org) module system can be intimidating, and it typically involves the use of many keywords—for example, `open` and `include`, which allow importing definitions into a module. Since version OCaml `4.08`, the `open` primitive has been *generalized* to allow the opening of **arbitrary module expressions**. In this article, we’ll explore how to use this generalization to reproduce a common practice in other languages, what I somewhat pompously call _import strategies_, to describe patterns like `import {a, b as c} from K`, without relying on a (_sub-_)language dedicated specifically to importing.
